newsitem.title: UK: UK exportable wheat surplus may be sold by end-Mar.
newsitem.headline: UK exportable wheat surplus may be sold by end-Mar.

text.p: The UK could have sold its wheat surplus from the 1996 harvest by the end of the month, traders said.
"Our figures, and I don't think they're very different from the ministry's, show that around four million tonnes have gone so far," one senior trader said.
He reckoned the total exportable surplus of some 4.2 million tonnes could be dealt with by the end of March.

But one analyst advised caution. "We haven't actually physically exported that much. What they (the trade) mean is that they've sold it," he said. If the market were to start to rise big players, in particular, could start switching to Danish or German origin, he said.
"But it does reflect the fact that the market is getting more balanced," he said.
Once the surplus is out of the way, the nature of the UK grain market will change, the trader said.

In recent months UK grain prices have been almost a function of sterling's value against the French franc and German mark, as UK grains have been forced to shadow "Sometimes it has felt like we've been trading sterling, not wheat," one trader said.
"Give it another month and you're back to dealing with domestic affairs," the first trader said.
The market would then become more sensitive to data on feed usage, final information on the exact size of the crop and the level of imports, he said.
